title: 109_s385
content: The "Rural America Preservation Act" may be cited as the short title. Payment limitations are outlined in the act. Section 1001 of the Food Security Act of 1985 is amended to limit marketing loan gains, loan deficiency payments, and commodity certificate transactions. The maximum amount a person can receive in gains and payments during a crop year is set at $75,000. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 limits loan rates for commodities and specifies conditions for settlement of marketing assistance loans. Loan deficiency payments and gains from commodity certificates are also regulated. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 regulates loan rates for commodities, settlement of marketing assistance loans, loan deficiency payments, and gains from commodity certificates. The act also includes provisions for single farming operations receiving payments or gains covered by the section. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 regulates loan rates, marketing assistance loans, loan deficiency payments, and gains from commodity certificates for farming operations. The act limits the total amount of payments or gains an individual or a couple may receive during a crop year. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 sets limits on the total payments and gains that an individual or couple may receive during a crop year, not exceeding twice the specified dollar amounts. Regulations are to be promulgated to ensure compliance with these limits for joint operations or multiple entities under the primary control of a person. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 imposes limits on payments and gains for individuals or couples involved in farming operations. Regulations will be enforced to ensure compliance with these limits for joint operations or multiple entities controlled by a single person. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 imposes limits on payments and gains for individuals or couples involved in farming operations where compensation is at risk, farm management services are provided by related parties, or more than 2/3 of farming operations are conducted. The Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 imposes limits on payments and gains for individuals or couples involved in farming operations where compensation is at risk, farm management services are provided by related parties, or more than 2/3 of farming operations are conducted. Farming operations may be conducted through custom farming services provided by the same person, an immediate family member, or an entity with a business relationship determined by the Secretary. The regulations aim to prevent payments exceeding specified dollar amounts and ensure that payments to others count towards the recipient's limit. Primary control is defined as ownership interest equal to or greater than others who participate in managing the operation. SEC. 3. SCHEMES OR DEVICES. Amends the Food Security Act of 1985 to address fraud in connection with schemes to evade certain sections, resulting in ineligibility for farm program payments for the crop year and the following 5 years. SEC. 4. REGULATIONS. The Secretary of Agriculture may issue regulations to implement the Act and its amendments without following certain procedural requirements. Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted under specified authority.
